Award.AwardTitle: Process Modeling and Enhancements of Laser-Induced Plasma Micro-Machining (LIP-MM)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The focus of this research is to gain deeper insight into the physics of the new process of Laser Induced Plasma Micromachining, which promises better and faster micro-feature fabrication as compared to conventional micro-machining with a focused laser beam. Physics-based models will be formulated for the investigation of the mechanisms of plasma generation, plasma-matter interaction, and the prediction of machined feature geometry. New optical techniques and unique enhancements to this process, based on the optical manipulation of the shape of the plasma into plasma patterns rather than a spot, will be explored. This will increase process productivity and speed by at least one order of magnitude, and facilitate the fabrication of two- and three-dimensional geometries and patterns. Comprehensive experiments involving all aspects of the mechanics of the process will also be performed to validate the models developed.

If successfully realized it is anticipated that the technology created by this project will enable major advances in critical areas of miniaturization technologies, given its multiple concomitant advantages such as its multi-materials capability, low heat-affected zone, high throughput, greater in-process flexibility and, most importantly, its pattern or feature/area-based rather than spot-based or writing nature of machining. This latter ability will result in significantly increased process throughput as compared to current focused laser beam based micro-manufacturing processes. Process capabilities will include the ability to generate high-accuracy features such as deep channels, dimples, through holes and other freeform structures on a variety of materials including metals, polymers, ceramics, composites and other transparent, reflective and brittle materials. The obtained results will also open doors for new research on non-lithography based single-step micro-manufacturing techniques for building and generating micro/meso-scale devices and patterns.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROCESS MODELING AND ENHANCEMENTS OF LASER-INDUCED PLASMA MICRO-MACHINING (LIP-MM)

OUTCOMES SUMMARY

The overall goal of this proposal was to understand the fundamental physics behind a new micromachining process - Laser Induced Plasma MicroMachining (LIP-MM) - and to devise mechanisms to enhance the performance of the basic process through various enhancements.  In LIP-MM, unlike in conventional laser ablation, in which the laser beam is directly focused on the surface of the part to remove material, the beam is focused slightly above the surface of the part that is submerged in a dielectric medium, e.g., distilled water. In this arrangement, microplasma is generated in the liquid dielectric medium at the focal point of the laser beam that, upon its expansion, performs controlled and directed micromachining/patterning/texturing of the workpiece through thermo-mechanical interactions.

The work performed focused on the following interrelated issues: (1) Formulation and experimental verification of physics-based models for the investigation of the mechanisms of material removal and microplasma behavior in LIP-MM for process planning and control; (2) Exploration of optical methods to generate a variety of microplasma patterns for pattern generation in a single laser discharge rather than by spot-by-spot processing that characterizes the ?writing? nature of the basic LIP-MM process and of conventional ablation processes to markedly increase throughput; (3) Experimental and analytical evaluation of different dielectric media from the standpoint of their plasma generation threshold to maximize material removal rates; and (4) Preliminary exploration of the possibility of using external controllable magnetic fields to shape and enhance the microplasma?s energy density, again, from the standpoint of the ability to generate simple patterns in a single laser discharge at high material removal rates.

In the course of the work it has been confirmed that the capabilities of the basic LIP-MM process can be markedly enhanced, while at the same time, offering a number of advantages over the basic LIP-MM process and existing ablation processes in terms of accuracy, impact on part/feature properties and productivity. The advantages include an expanded multi-materials capability, reduced heat-affected zones, greater process flexibility in terms of possible microfeature shapes and, most importantly, overcoming the writing or spot-by-spot based nature of LIP-MM as well as of conventional ablation through the possibility of creating multiple features in a single laser exposure. This latter ability results in significantly increased process throughput as compared to current laser-based micro-manufacturing processes.

The pragmatic application areas of LIP-MM span the range from single microfeatures to functional surface textures over large areas of free-form surfaces. The highest potential impacts include, but are not limited to prolonged implant life in the biomedical sector achieved through surface texturing, increased energy efficiency of solar cells, energy savings via a reduction in friction in contacting and bearing surfaces and engine parts, enabling the use of refractory ceramic materials for increased energy efficiency of fuel cells and the use of materials like glass in microfluidics devices for tissue cell engineering, materials synthesis and point-of-need diagnostics to name a few.

From the standpoint of its scientific impact the proposed work has resulted in a number of fundamental models that address the physics of microplasma generation/evolution, its interaction with target materials and its manipulation and control by optical means, through the choice of the proper dielectric and through external magnetic fields. None of these models and methods have been applied so far in the context of micromachining/micropatterning in their stand-alone or their integrated form. The newly obtained basic knowledge will be usefull as a guide for creating advanced LIP-MM-based process variants with their concomitant advantages as well as process control capabilities.

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2018
Modified by: Kornel F Ehmann
